key_insight: AnyAD learns a single, modality-agnostic anomaly detection model that reliably detects brain MRI anomalies from any subset of available sequences, removing the need to train separate models for each modality combination.
problem_solved: Clinical MRI workflows often miss one or more sequences and annotated abnormal cases are scarce; existing AD models assume fixed modality inputs or require repeated retraining and so fail to scale to arbitrary, incomplete multi-sequence inputs.
method: Train a unified representation that accepts variable sets of MRI sequences by simulating missing modalities during training (modality dropout / masked inputs).
Learn anomaly scoring in the shared latent space (e.g., reconstruction error or latent-density based) so scores are comparable across different input subsets.
Deploy a single model that performs inference on any combination of available sequences without retraining, enabling robust AD in incomplete multi-sequence MRI.
impact: Enables scalable, clinically practical MRI anomaly detection that tolerates missing sequences and reduces repeated model training; lowers deployment burden and improves robustness of ML systems in heterogeneous imaging environments.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: variable-set MRI inputs → modality-agnostic encoder → anomaly scorer (reconstruction/latent density) → anomaly map/score.
Illustration of modality dropout: show training with full and partial sequence sets to indicate robustness to missing data.
Performance chart: AUC/ROC or detection accuracy comparing AnyAD (single model) vs. per-combination baselines across multiple missing-modality scenarios.
t-SNE or latent-space visualization: normal vs. anomalous sample separation when using mixed modality inputs.
paper_title: AnyAD: Unified Any-Modality Anomaly Detection in Incomplete Multi-Sequence MRI
paper_authors: Changwei Wu, Yifei Chen, Yuxin Du, Mingxuan Liu, Jinying Zong
